item.title: Dollar Falls as Trump Pressures Powell; Futures Up: Markets Wrap
item.description: The dollar fell as traders ramped up bets for faster US interest-rate cuts, spurred by a report that President Donald Trump may fast-track his nomination for the next Federal Reserve chief. Stock futures advanced.
item.dc:creator: Andre Janse Van Vuuren, Matthew Thomas

item.title: Jes Staley Loses Bid to Overturn Ban Over Epstein Relationship
item.description: Former Barclays Plc boss Jes Staley lost a legal battle to overturn his ban from the City watchdog over his relationship with Jeffrey Epstein, all but ending his attempt to rehabilitate himself in the British financial services industry.
item.dc:creator: Jeremy Hodges

media:content.media:description: Jes Staley departs from The Rolls Building in London in March. Photographer: Jaimi Joy/Bloomberg

item.title: Platinum Jumps to Highest Since 2014 on Mounting Supply Concerns
item.description: Platinum surged to its highest level since 2014 as supply concerns and a wave of speculative buying jolted the market.
item.dc:creator: Yihui Xie, Jack Ryan

item.title: Tanker Seen Near Russia’s Arctic LNG 2 for First Time in Months
item.description: A liquefied natural gas tanker appears to be heading to a Russian Arctic export plant sanctioned by the US, potentially Moscow’s latest efforts to revive shipments from a facility idled for eight months.
item.dc:creator: Stephen Stapczynski, Anna Shiryaevskaya

media:content.media:description: LNG tanker Iris appears to be headed to Arctic LNG 2 (grey dot on the map) after passing the operational Yamal LNG plant (green dot).

item.title: Animal Spirits Are Back in Asia as Fears of Trade War Ebb
item.description: From stocks to currencies to credit, the rebound from the depths of the April market turmoil has been impressive
item.dc:creator: Bailey Lipschultz, Alice French, Phil Serafino

item.title: Solar Manufacturer Meyer Burger’s US Units File for Bankruptcy
item.description: Meyer Burger Technology AG’s US operations have filed for Chapter 11 proceedings with the aim of selling all or most of the Swiss-headquartered solar manufacturer’s assets in the country.
item.dc:creator: Libby Cherry

media:content.media:description: Rows of photovoltaic panels. Photographer: Angel Garcia/Bloomberg

item.title: Lithuania Calls on EU to Help Fund Securing Eastern Border
item.description: Lithuanian President Gitanas Nauseda called on the European Union to help finance the fortification of the bloc’s eastern borders as the expenses strain national budgets.
item.dc:creator: Milda Seputyte

media:content.media:description: Dragon's teeth fortifications near Latvia's border with Russia.

item.title: US Bank Stocks Revival Depends on Relaxed Rules and Deal Recovery
item.description: Loosening regulations, the steady drumbeat of dealmaking, elevated interest rates: It’s a recipe for US banking stocks shares to rip higher.
item.dc:creator: Georgie McKay

item.title: Trump Ratchets up Powell Pressure, Russia Sanctions on EU Summit Agenda | Bloomberg The Pulse 06/26
item.description:
President Donald Trump said he has three or four people in mind to succeed Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell when his term expires next year. “I know within three or four people,” Trump said Wednesday during a press conference at The Hague, where he is attending the NATO summit. “I mean he goes out pretty soon, fortunately, because I think he’s terrible.” Trump did not name his potential replacements for the central banker nor did he lay out a timeline for a decision. Powell’s term as chair ends in May 2026. In Brussels, EU leaders are meeting to discuss fresh sanctions on Russia, US tariffs and their response to the Middle East conflicts.
Today's guests: Beata Manthey, Citi European Equity Strategy Head, Carl Bildt, European Council for Foreign Relations Co-Chair & former Swedish Prime Minister, George Arison, Grindr CEO, Chuka Umunna, JPMorgan Global Head of Sustainable Solutions & EMEA Head of Green Economy Investment Banking (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: South African President Weighing Changes to Cabinet, News24 Says
item.description: South African President Cyril Ramaphosa is weighing changes to his cabinet, including removing the nation’s deputy trade minister who’s a member of the second-largest party in the ruling coalition.
item.dc:creator: Paul Vecchiatto

item.title: Iraq Says US Company Among Bidders as It Plans First LNG Imports
item.description: Iraq is in advanced talks with Excelerate Energy Inc. to facilitate its first-ever liquefied natural gas imports as the country, which struggles with power outages, seeks to cut dependence on Iran for supplies.
item.dc:creator: Khalid Al Ansary, Verity Ratcliffe

media:content.media:description: An LNG vessel. Photographer: Dwayne Senior/Bloomberg

item.title: Dollar Falls as Trump Ratchets Up Powell Replacement Pressure | The Opening Trade 06/26
item.description:
The dollar fell and Treasury yields declined on bets that US interest-rate cuts could come sooner than expected, following a report that President Donald Trump may fast-track his pick for the next Federal Reserve chair. The moves followed a Wall Street Journal report that Trump may announce Jerome Powell’s replacement as soon as September, an unusually early appointment.
The Fed unveiled plans to roll back an important capital rule that big banks have said limits their ability to hold more Treasuries and Shell said it has no intention of making a takeover offer for BP refuting an earlier report that two of Europe’s biggest companies were in active merger talks.
The Opening Trade has everything you need to know as markets open across Europe. With analysis you won't find anywhere else, we break down the biggest stories of the day and speak to top guests who have skin in the game. Hosted by Anna Edwards, Guy Johnson and Kriti Gupta. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: South Korea to Announce Measures to Cool House Prices, Yonhap
item.description: South Korea plans to announce measures to stabilize spiraling house prices early next month, including tightening lending and tax regulations for overheated areas around Seoul, Yonhap News reported Thursday, citing unnamed sources.
item.dc:creator: Hyonhee Shin, Shinhye Kang

media:content.media:description: Apartments in Seoul. Photographer: Tina Hsu/Bloomberg

item.title: Oil Holds Near $68 With Focus Turning to Iran Talks, OPEC+ Plans
item.description: Oil steadied after US President Donald Trump said his maximum pressure campaign on Iran will continue.
item.dc:creator: Sarah Chen, Alex Longley

item.title: Citi Says Volatility Could Rise as Tariff Deadline Nears
item.description: Citigroup Inc. strategist Beata Manthey comments on the outlook for European stocks and the potential for heightened volatility amid geopolitical risks and as US President Donald Trump’s tariff deadline nears. She speaks on Bloomberg Television.

item.title: S&P 500 Chart Watchers Fret Over Rally’s Narrow Leadership Ranks
item.description: With technology stocks powering major US indexes toward record highs, technical analysts see the makings of a selloff in the coming months unless more sectors join the rally.
item.dc:creator: Esha Dey

item.title: Markets Are Facing Classic Wall of Worry: HSBC’s Kettner
item.description: “Investors are underestimating, heavily, how much we could see a melt up and a squeeze into the summer months,” says Max Kettner, chief multi-asset strategist at HSBC, as he explains the upside catalysts he sees for markets.

item.title: Thai Cannabis Industry Thrown Into Chaos as Government Aims to Recriminalize Weed
item.description: Three years after becoming the first Asian nation to decriminalize cannabis, Thailand is poised to reverse course amid political turmoil and now requires a prescription to buy cannabis at any of the 10,000 dispensaries that have sprung up since 2022.
item.dc:creator: Patpicha Tanakasempipat

media:content.media:description: A cannabis store on Silom Road in Bangkok.

item.title: China to Relax Urea Export Ban, Easing Global Price Pressure
item.description: China is loosening its ban on urea exports, a move likely to ease international prices that have been buoyed by the recent tension in the Middle East.
item.dc:creator: Hallie Gu, Alfred Cang

media:content.media:description: Shipping containers at the Yantian International Container Terminals in Shenzhen, China. Photographer: Qilai Shen/Bloomberg

item.title: Transnet Coal Shipments Rise as Security Improves, Thungela Says
item.description: South Africa’s state logistics company has ramped up deliveries of coal on the country’s main export rail line after addressing operational and security-related issues, according to Thungela Resources Ltd.
item.dc:creator: Paul Burkhardt

media:content.media:description: A Transnet freight train transports coal from a mine in Mpumalanga, South Africa.

item.title: Asian Markets in Full Swing as Investors Shake Off Trade Jitters
item.description: Trading desks across Asia are buzzing with excitement again, as the region shakes off tariff shocks and attracts investors with its solid growth prospects.
item.dc:creator: Bailey Lipschultz, Alice French

item.title: FTSE 100 Live: Pound Rallies to October 2021 High Against Dollar
China Opens First Offshore Gold Vault in Hong Kong
item.description: The Shanghai Gold Exchange has expanded outside mainland China for the first time, with the rollout of two new contracts and a bullion vault in Hong Kong.
item.dc:creator: Yihui Xie, Sybilla Gross

item.title: The Company That Wants To Bring Back Supersonic Jet Travel
item.description: Can Boom succeed where the Concorde failed?
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

item.title: Odd Lots: The US Company Building a New Supersonic Jet (Podcast)
item.description: We talk all the time about the US attempting to become a powerhouse in advanced manufacturing, but a lot of it just sounds like talk that’s not going anywhere. But some companies are trying. Boom Supersonic is an 11-year old company that has raised hundreds of millions of dollars in its quest to build a new supersonic jet for commercial air passengers. And it believes that just because the business model of the Concorde didn’t work out in the end, that there’s no reason there can’t be a market f
item.dc:creator: Tracy Alloway, Joe Weisenthal

item.title: Foreign Buying in Japan Stocks Hits 12-Week Streak : TSE Data
item.description: Foreign investors were net buyers of Japanese stocks for the 12th consecutive week, according to data from Tokyo Stock Exchange operator, the Japan Exchange Group.
item.dc:creator: Hideyuki Sano, Momoka Yokoyama

item.title: Czech Defense Firm Increases Junk Bond Sale to $2.16 Billion
item.description: Armaments maker Czechoslovak Group AS raised $2.16 billion through a junk bond sale, more than double its original intention, highlighting the relentless clamor for the defense sector among credit money managers.
item.dc:creator: Abhinav Ramnarayan, Rose Henderson

media:content.media:description: Czechoslovak Group’s Pandur 8x8 EVO wheeled armored vehicle in Brno.

item.title: South Korea Kicks Off First Euro Bond Sale in Nearly Four Years
item.description: The South Korean government kicked off its first euro-denominated bond sale in nearly four years on Thursday, in a test of investor appetite following the recent election of President Lee Jae Myung that ended months of political turmoil.
item.dc:creator: Haram Lim

media:content.media:description: The National Assembly building in Seoul, South Korea, on Monday, April 7, 2025. South Korea has set June 3 as the tentative date for the next presidential election, Yonhap News reported on Monday, citing an unidentified government official.

item.title: The Asia Trade 06/26/2025
item.description: "Bloomberg: The Asia Trade" brings you everything you need to know to get ahead as the trading day begins in Asia. Bloomberg TV is live from Singapore and Sydney with Avril Hong and Haidi Stroud-Watts, getting insight and analysis from newsmakers and industry leaders on the biggest stories shaping global markets. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: BCC Director General Shevaun Haviland on BTV
item.description: The Director General of the British Chambers of Commerce, Shevaun Haviland, speaks with Bloomberg's Joe Mayes about the UK economy, trade and corporate taxation. Interview was recorded on June 25. (Source: Bloomberg)
